I will give an illustration for the difference between a random search and =
a search directed by a random fitness function.
Imagine you have a hilly la=
ndscape and you want to plant a flag as high as possible on the landscape.
=
A random search would be to airdrop a thousand people at uniformly random l=
ocations and each person will plant a flag at the spot where he lands.
A se=
arch with a random fitness function would be to drop one person with a thou=
sand flags. This person will at each timestep choose a random direction, wa=
lk a few steps and plant a flag.
In the first case you will get a represent=
ative sample of the landscape. In the second you get a trail with the diffe=
rent flags being at similar heights. He might land on the planes and miss t=
he hills altogether. The landscape will be poorly represented.
A more sophi=
sticated search algorithm, will reduce the impact of this problem, as the p=
erson will sometimes jump to faraway locations. The problem however will ne=
ver be eliminated, as a kind of a local search is in integral part of any f=
itness directed search algorithm.

Additionally, I think there should be an=
other subtler problem with random fitness directed search, which will manif=
est itself in representations with variable size genotypes. It will cause t=
he code size to grow much faster than what is optimally wanted in a random =
search and produce overly convoluted solutions, where in reality we we want=
 the solutions to be simple.

then compare it in the same domain (and other domains, if you want to be th=
orough).  Of course, if you found that any type of completely random proces=
s consistently outperforms fitness significantly in reasonable domains (as =
novelty does) it would be a huge shock.   
> 
> You suggest that the random=
 search that we implemented is worse than the kind of random search that yo=
u describe.  I could be wrong, but I don't think there is an a priori reaso=
n to believe that any given totally uninformed process is better than anoth=
er.  You note that our random search may be more "uneven," which could be t=
rue, but there is no a priori reason to believe that being "even" is better=
 for a given domain.  Generally, even with totally random searches you are =
facing a kind of no free lunch situation.
> 
> Probably the most important =
question underlying your curiosity is why we would expect novelty to be bet=
ter than random.  There are many answers to this question, but perhaps one =
helpful insight is that novelty is an informative gradient.  That is, quite=
 the opposite of random search, novelty is information-rich, which means th=
at the novelty metric tells us a lot about how different points in the sear=
ch space relate to each other.  In fact, one way to understand the relation=
ship among random, fitness, and novelty, is to realize that fitness actuall=
y provides less information than novelty, putting it between random and nov=
elty on the scale of information-richness.  The reason fitness provides les=
s information is that many behaviors that are different from each other rec=
eive the same fitness, whereas novelty search would notice their difference=
.  Thus, in fitness-based search, moving among such conflated behaviors is =
similar to a random search, because there is no gradient among them.  
>
